questions.text: A 1-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with congenital heart defects, characteristic facial anomalies including hypertelorism and low-set ears, and recurrent viral and fungal infections. There is also evidence of hypocalcemia. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) DiGeorge syndrome

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the clinic due to a friendly and outgoing personality, along with distinct facial features such as a wide mouth, full lips, and a flattened nasal bridge. Physical examination reveals supravalvular aortic stenosis and peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis. The child also has developmental delays and a characteristic 'elfin' appearance. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Williams syndrome

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A friendly and outgoing personality combined with "elfin" facial features and supravalvular aortic stenosis strongly suggests Williams syndrome.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9412
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9412

questions.text: A newborn presents with cyanosis and respiratory distress shortly after birth. A physical examination reveals a single loud second heart sound and a continuous murmur along the left sternal border. An echocardiogram confirms a parallel circulation. What is the most likely diagnosis for this clinical presentation?
questions.correct_answer: C. Transposition of the great arteries
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Transposition of the great arteries

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transposition of the great arteries is a neonatal emergency characterized by cyanosis, parallel circulation, and a single loud second heart sound. It requires prostaglandin infusion, temporary mixing procedures, and definitive surgical repair.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9337
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9337

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant is evaluated for suspected congenital heart disease. On examination, a harsh, holosystolic murmur grade 4 is auscultated at the left sternal border, with radiation to the back. Additionally, the second heart sound is widely split. Which of the following represents a major criterion of Nadas criteria for diagnosing ventricular septal defect (VSD) in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Harsh systolic murmur grade 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In infants with suspected VSD, a harsh, holosystolic murmur of grade 3 or more is a major diagnostic criterion as per Nadas criteria and should prompt further evaluation.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with congenital heart defects and upper limb abnormalities, including absent or hypoplastic thumbs. Cardiac evaluation reveals an atrial septal defect and a ventricular septal defect. Which of the following syndromes is most commonly associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Holt-Oram syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Holt-Oram syndrome is characterized by upper limb abnormalities, such as absent or hypoplastic thumbs, and congenital heart defects, most commonly ostium secundum atrial septal defect.

questions.text: A neonate is diagnosed with ductal-dependent congenital heart disease. The medical team plans to initiate prostaglandin therapy to maintain ductal patency. Which of the following medications is commonly used in this context to prevent ductal closure and improve systemic or pulmonary blood flow in critically ill neonates with congenital heart defects?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Alprostadil

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alprostadil (PGE1) is the standard medication to maintain ductal patency in neonates with ductal-dependent congenital heart diseases.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with cyanosis, clubbing of fingers, and polycythemia. Echocardiography reveals an intracardiac shunt allowing deoxygenated blood to bypass the pulmonary circulation. Which of the following types of cardiac shunts is characterized by the flow of deoxygenated blood from the right side of the heart to the left side, resulting in the systemic circulation receiving poorly oxygenated blood?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tetralogy of Fallot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tetralogy of Fallot is a cyanotic congenital heart defect caused by a right-to-left shunt, resulting in deoxygenated blood entering systemic circulation, leading to cyanosis, clubbing, and polycythemia .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: A 14-year-old female presents with exertional dyspnea and fatigue. Physical examination reveals a loud first heart sound, a mid-diastolic murmur, and a widely split second heart sound. Echocardiography confirms the presence of an atrial septal defect and a severely stenosed mitral valve. Which of the following conditions is characterized by the combination of these two cardiac abnormalities, leading to symptoms of pulmonary congestion and right heart volume overload?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lutembacher syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lutembacher syndrome is characterized by the combination of atrial septal defect (ASD) and mitral stenosis, leading to a unique clinical presentation of wide fixed S2, mid-diastolic murmur, and pulmonary congestion.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with severe pulmonary hypertension secondary to left-sided heart disease undergoes a surgical procedure that creates a direct communication between the descending aorta and the left pulmonary artery. Which of the following terms is used to describe this surgical shunt, designed to relieve pulmonary hypertension by redirecting blood flow from the systemic circulation to the pulmonary vasculature?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Potts shunt

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Potts shunt is a surgical connection between the descending aorta and the left pulmonary artery, designed to alleviate pulmonary hypertension by redirecting systemic blood to the pulmonary vasculature.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a history of diarrhea. Physical examination reveals a scaly rash on sun-exposed areas, glossitis, and dementia like symptoms. Their family have a habit of eating maize. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pellagra

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pellagra, caused by niacin deficiency, presents with photosensitive dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, often associated with maize-based diets due to low niacin and tryptophan content .

questions.text: A 5-year-old child from a low-income community presents with dry, inflamed eyes and white foamy patches on the bulbar conjunctiva. Physical examination reveals growth retardation and impaired night vision. The child's diet is primarily limited to starchy foods. Which of the following is the most common sign associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 3-year-old child from a low-income community presents with profound muscle weakness, lower limb edema, and irritability. Physical examination reveals a symmetrical peripheral neuropathy with loss of deep tendon reflexes. The child's diet primarily consists of polished rice. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Beriberi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Beriberi, caused by thiamine deficiency, presents with muscle weakness, peripheral neuropathy, and, in wet beriberi, cardiac symptoms like edema. Polished rice diets are a major risk factor.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1944
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1944

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with seizures and irritability. Physical examination reveals a scaly, erythematous rash around the mouth and on the cheeks. The child has a history of exclusive breastfeeding without any supplementation. Laboratory tests show decreased levels of neurotransmitters. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pyridoxine deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyridoxine deficiency is the most common vitamin deficiency causing seizures in infants, characterized by irritability, scaly rash, and decreased neurotransmitter levels due to impaired GABA synthesis.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 3299
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 3299

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate is brought to the emergency department with bleeding from the umbilical stump and ecchymoses on the skin. The mother reports a normal pregnancy by dai in a village and uncomplicated delivery. Laboratory tests reveal prolonged prothrombin time and normal platelet count, baby is on exclusive breast feeding. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin K deficiency.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn (HDN) caused by vitamin K deficiency is the most common cause of umbilical bleeding in neonates. Early prophylactic vitamin K administration at birth is crucial to prevent this condition.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl develops profuse, foul-smelling diarrhea after ingesting contaminated water during a camping trip. Stool analysis was done. Mother is worried that the child passes worm in the stool. What is the most appropriate treatment for the patient’s worm infestation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Albendazole.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of "teardrop" cells in stool analysis after ingesting contaminated water is indicative of a parasitic infestation, for which albendazole is the treatment of choice.
  • ➤ albendazole
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 7259
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 7259

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents with irritability, poor weight gain, and frequent regurgitation after feeds. The mother reports that the infant arches the back and cries during feeding. What is the most likely diagnosis for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ GERD is the most likely diagnosis in infants presenting with arching the back and crying during feeds , along with poor weight gain and regurgitation. This condition is caused by esophageal irritation from gastric reflux.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is evaluated for recurrent abdominal pain, bloating, and intermittent diarrhea. She reports discomfort after consuming wheat-based products. Serologic testing reveals elevated anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA). What is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this child's suspected celiac disease?

options.label: C

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is admitted with severe dehydration due to acute gastroenteritis. What is the appropriate concentration of potassium in oral rehydration solution (ORS) for the initial management of this child's dehydration?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 20 mEq/L

questions.text: A newborn is suspected to have tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) due to excessive salivation, choking during feeds, and a polyhydramnios history. Which type of TEF may be indicative, considering the absence of air in the abdomen on X-ray?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Type A, B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Type A or Type B TEF

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician due to developmental delays and facial abnormalities. Physical examination reveals a smooth philtrum, thin upper lip, and a small head circumference. The child demonstrates poor coordination and exhibits behavioral problems. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fetal alcohol syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of smooth philtrum , thin upper lip , and microcephaly , along with developmental and behavioral issues, strongly suggests Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) as the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A newborn infant is brought to the neonatal unit with multiple congenital anomalies including clenched fists, overlapping fingers, and a prominent occiput. Further evaluation reveals a low-set malformed ear and a small jaw and foot deformity. Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities is most likely responsible for these clinical features?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of clenched fists with overlapping fingers , rocker-bottom feet , and other congenital anomalies strongly suggests Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) . This condition is associated with severe malformations, high mortality, and significant developmental delays.

questions.explanation:

questions.text: A newborn infant is brought to the pediatrician due to macrosomia, macroglossia, and omphalocele. Further examination reveals visceromegaly and hemihypertrophy of the body. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a high-pitched cat-like cry, microcephaly, and severe intellectual disability. Physical examination reveals a round face, hypertelorism, and a small jaw. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 1-year-old child is brought to the clinic for a developmental assessment. Physical examination reveals upward slanting of the palpebral fissures, a flattened nasal bridge, and a protruding tongue. The child demonstrates single transverse palmar creases and hypotonia. Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Down syndrome

  • ➤ The presence of upward slanting palpebral fissures flattened nasal bridge , single transverse palmar crease , and hypotonia strongly suggests Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) .

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with developmental delays and behavioral problems. Physical examination reveals long and narrow face, large ears, and macroorchidism. Further evaluation shows an expanded CGG trinucleotide repeat in the FMR1 gene. Which of the following genetic conditions is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fragile X syndrome

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fragile X syndrome is caused by a CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene and is characterized by developmental delay, a long, narrow face, large ears, and macroorchidism. These findings are pathognomonic for this condition.

questions.text: A 28-year-old couple were trying to conceive, they went to the gynaecologist. On further examination, the husband was having tall stature, gynecomastia, small testes, and sparse body hair. Physical examination reveals long limbs and a eunuchoid body shape. Karyotype analysis was advised. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Klinefelter syndrome

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY) presents with tall stature, gynecomastia, small testes, sparse body hair, and infertility due to primary hypogonadism. It is confirmed by karyotype analysis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to short stature, characteristic facial features including hypertelorism and downward-slanting palpebral fissures, and a webbed neck. Cardiac evaluation reveals pulmonary valve stenosis and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Which of the following genetic syndromes is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Noonan syndrome.

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Noonan syndrome is characterized by short stature, hypertelorism, downward-slanting palpebral fissures, webbed neck, and congenital cardiac defects such as pulmonary valve stenosis and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. It affects both males and females.

questions.text: A newborn infant is brought to the neonatal unit with multiple congenital anomalies, including cleft lip and palate, polydactyly, and microphthalmia. Cardiac evaluation reveals a ventricular septal defect. Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Patau syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13) is associated with cleft lip and palate, polydactyly, microphthalmia, and cardiac defects such as ventricular septal defect. These findings are characteristic of this chromosomal abnormality.

questions.text: A neonate is born with a cleft palate, micrognathia, and glossoptosis, leading to airway obstruction and difficulty in feeding. Physical examination reveals a U-shaped cleft palate and a receding chin. Which of the following syndromes is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pierre Robin syndrome.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pierre Robin syndrome is characterized by micrognathia, glossoptosis, and a U-shaped cleft palate. These features often lead to feeding difficulties and airway obstruction in neonates.

  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 3513

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic with obesity, hypotonia, and excessive eating behavior. Physical examination reveals almond-shaped eyes, a thin upper lip, and small hands and feet. Which of the following genetic disorders is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Prader-Willi syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prader-Willi syndrome is characterized by hyperphagia, obesity, hypotonia, almond-shaped eyes, a thin upper lip, and small hands and feet. It is caused by paternal gene defects on chromosome 15q11-q13.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic with intellectual disability, broad thumbs, and a characteristic facial appearance including down-slanting palpebral fissures and a beaked nose. Physical examination reveals a prominent forehead and low-set ears. Which of the following genetic disorders is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome is characterized by intellectual disability, broad thumbs, and a distinctive facial appearance with down-slanting palpebral fissures, a beaked nose, and low-set ears. Broad thumbs are a key identifying feature of this condition.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to an abnormal head shape. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) trigonocephaly

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trigonocephaly is caused by the premature fusion of the metopic suture and is characterized by a triangular-shaped forehead with a prominent ridge and hypotelorism. It is a specific type of craniosynostosis.

  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 3034

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic for a routine check-up. On examination, the head circumference is found to be significantly smaller than the 3rd SD, while the height and weight are at the 50th percentile. The infant demonstrates irritability and increased muscle tone. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Microcephaly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Microcephaly is defined by a head circumference below the 3rd percentile and is often associated with normal growth of height and weight. It may also present with neurological symptoms such as hypertonia and irritability.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to concerns about his growth and development. Physical examination reveals macrocephaly, a prominent jaw, and a pointed chin. His height and weight are both above the 97th percentile for his age, and he has advanced bone age. The child's developmental milestones are appropriate for his age. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sotos syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sotos syndrome is characterized by childhood overgrowth, macrocephaly, advanced bone age, and distinctive facial features such as a prominent jaw and pointed chin. It is a key differential diagnosis in cases of overgrowth syndromes.

  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 11,319

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with downward slanting eyes, absence of lower eyelashes, and bilateral external ear anomalies characterized by hypoplastic, malformed, or absent pinnae. The child also has a small mandible and cleft palate. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Treacher Collins syndrome.

Educational Objective:
